KEREN ANN (Monday) With exquisitely delicate, sensuous songs that seem never to touch the ground, Keren Ann Zeidel -- born in Tel Aviv and raised in Paris -- is the model of the modern cosmopolitan chanteuse, part jazzy, part indie-cabaret and part glam-folk. With Jason Hart. At 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $15. (Ben Sisario)

ALAN BERGMAN (Tuesday) With a new album, ''Lyrically, Alan Bergman'' (Verve), this three-time Oscar-winning songwriter (''The Windmills of Your Mind,'' ''The Way We Were'') makes a rare appearance at Joe's Pub. At 9:30 p.m., 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $25. (Sisario)

BRAZZAVILLE (Tonight) While playing saxophone for Beck in the '90s, David Brown learned guitar and started Brazzaville, writing languid, bittersweet songs in a multicultural update of the vagabond cabaret of Tom Waits and Tindersticks. Four years ago he relocated to Barcelona and formed a new version of the band, still singing about crumbling cafes and the way his former lovers held their cigarettes. The new Brazzaville makes its American debut tonight at 9:30 at Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $15. (Sisario)

* BRIGHT EYES (Tonight) In the indie-rock equivalent of Bruce Springsteen's filling up Giants Stadium for weeks on end, Bright Eyes -- consisting of the excessively confessional man-child Conor Oberst (dressed in Prada these days) and whomever he's playing with -- has sold out seven shows at Town Hall, ending tonight. His guest is Gillian Welch, who plays a mellow bluegrass-folk hybrid with grace. At 7:30, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, the-townhall-nyc.org. (Sisario)

CALIFONE (Thursday) A mainstay of the Chicago experimental-rock scene, Califone plays wistful songs with a constant thin hum. With the Bitter Tears and Curtis Harvey. At 8 p.m., Blender Theater at Gramercy, 127 East 23rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171; $15. (Sisario)

* JUDY COLLINS (Tuesday through Thursday) What Ms. Collins brings to a song, whether she wrote it or not, is perspective. You have the sense of a woman standing alone in the night air, gazing at a star and directing a beam of psychic energy into the cosmos. Or maybe she is the receiver of this cool, steady light; it cuts both ways. She is back at the Café Carlyle for a series of encore performances. At 8:45 p.m., Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $150 cover at tables, $100 at the bar. (Stephen Holden)

CSS (Tonight) Over bare, exuberant and deliberately amateurish art-funk, this mostly female Brazilian group celebrates the sacrament of casual sex through come-ons shouted and mumbled in robotic, broken English. (''Kiss-kiss-kiss will make this earth quake.'') With Yo Majesty. At 9, Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $20. (Sisario)

* DATAROCK (Tomorrow) It might seem impossible at this point to find something new on the well-traveled path of electro dance-rock. But somehow this Norwegian duo does it, with spiky disco, a full supply of funk guitar riffs and a rock 'n' roll attitude that mixes snarls with catchy, silly ''Fa-fa-fa fa-fa-fa-fa-fa'' choruses. With Low Bee and Passions. At 10 p.m., Studio B, 259 Banker Street, between Meserole Avenue and Calyer Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-1880, clubstudiob.com; $10. (Sisario)

DEAN AND BRITTA (Tomorrow) In Luna, Dean Wareham expertly channeled the cool, slow-shifting guitar clouds of the mid-period Velvet Underground. Since dissolving Luna two years ago, he has been playing with its former bassist, Britta Phillips, and on their new album, ''Back Numbers'' (Zoe/Rounder), they emulate, with unfortunate stiffness, another touchstone of 1960s cool: the bare, dissolute country of Lee Hazlewood and Nancy Sinatra. With My Robot Friend. At 9:30 p.m., Luna Lounge, 361 Metropolitan Avenue, at Havemeyer Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (212) 307-7171, lunalounge.com; $18. (Sisario)

* DINOSAUR JR., AWESOME COLOR (Wednesday and Thursday) One of the greatest and most influential original grunge bands, Dinosaur Jr. joined mopey lyrics to furious guitar sludge, prefiguring Nirvana. Long estranged, the original lineup of J Mascis on guitar, Lou Barlow on bass and Murph on drums reunited two years ago and just released ''Beyond'' (Fat Possum), their first album together in 18 years, sounding as brawny and vigorous as ever. Awesome Color's gruff, retro garage-blues is self-consciously noisy as only New York rock can be, but it is also indebted -- and seems partly a homage -- to the vintage Detroit proto-punk of the Stooges and the MC5. At 9 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $25. (Sisario)

JOHN DOE (Wednesday and Thursday) In the seminal Los Angeles punk band X and on his own, John Doe has linked a rugged sentimentality to twangy, rockabilly-tinged songs, and is particularly good at singing with women. His latest, ''A Year in the Wilderness'' (Yep Roc), features Aimee Mann, Jill Sobule and Kathleen Edwards aside longtime collaborators like the guitarist Dave Alvin. Wednesday at 9 p.m., BAMCafé, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; no cover. Thursday at 8 p.m., Living Room, 154 Ludlow Street, near Stanton Street, Lower East Side, (212) 533-7235, livingroomny.com; $10. (Sisario)

* ROKY ERICKSON AND ALEJANDRO ESCOVEDO (Tomorrow) One of the godfathers of psychedelic rock, who howled like a werewolf over the flutter of an electric jug in his 1960s band the 13th Floor Elevators, Roky Erickson is also one of the most notorious casualties of that era. Now, at 59 and in his best health in years, he is back on the road with a tough, no-nonsense band, and at his belated New York debut seven weeks ago tore through classics like ''You're Gonna Miss Me'' with ease and lots of low-end guitar fuzz. Alejandro Escovedo's songs stare down loss and mortality with a mixture of unflinching memory and a rocker's defiance. At 7 p.m., Castle Clinton National Monument, Battery Park, Lower Manhattan, (212) 835-2789, rivertorivernyc.com. Free; tickets available at 5 p.m., two per person. (Sisario)

FAIRPORT CONVENTION (Sunday) One original member and two later recruits of this groundbreaking British progressive-folk group from the 1960s and '70s -- the guitarist Simon Nicol, who was in it from the beginning, along with the violinist and mandolin player Chris Leslie and the violinist Ric Sanders -- play an acoustic set of Fairport Convention songs, jazz and swing standards and traditional folk. At 7 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $25. (Sisario)

MARIANNE FAITHFULL (Wednesday) Marianne Faithfull applies her husky ruin of a voice to songs about harrowing moments and bitter realizations. In songs she wrote herself or chose with exacting standards, she reveals every scar with bleak fascination and no regrets. At 8 p.m., Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues, (212) 307-7171; $75. (Jon Pareles)

FALL OUT BOY, +44, THE ACADEMY IS , PAUL WALL, COBRA STARSHIP (Tuesday and Wednesday) They could have called it Monsters of Emo, but certain considerations led to a name that is less rock 'n' roll but perhaps just as indicative of mainstream success: the Honda Civic Tour. Fall Out Boy remains the model second-wave (or is this the third?) emo band: snarky and jumpy, interested in relationships over solitude, and bursting with melodic pop-punk riffs. Also on the bill are +44, with Mark Hoppus and Travis Barker of Blink-182; the Houston rapper Paul Wall; and Cobra Starship, adrift in a sea of dance-punk irony. Tuesday at 6 p.m., Nikon at Jones Beach Theater, Wantagh, N.Y., (516) 221-1000, nikonjonesbeach.com; $25 and $40. Wednesday at 6 p.m., PNC Bank Arts Center, Holmdel, N.J., (732) 335-8698, artscenter.com; $23.75 and $39.50. (Sisario)

NELLY FURTADO (Thursday) Last year Ms. Furtado and Justin Timberlake demonstrated a truism of 21st-century pop: work with Timbaland and ye shall receive bucketfuls of hits and be reborn as a star. Opening the show are Kenna and Saukrates. At 8 p.m., WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741 or (212) 307-4111, thegarden.com; $45 to $65. (Sisario)

THE HORRORS (Monday) Recalling the early Damned, this British band sticks to dark, cold and gloomy in its albums but comes alive -- or is that fully undead? -- onstage. With Schoolyard Heroes and Night Kills The Day. At 8:30 p.m., Luna Lounge, 361 Metropolitan Avenue, at Havemeyer Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (212) 307-7171, lunalounge.com; $14. (Sisario)

* HOT 97 SUMMER JAM (Sunday) This annual mega-concert presented by the radio station Hot 97 (WQHT-FM) is always one of the most talked-about hip-hop events in the country, as much because of the starry lineup as because of the sparks that sometimes fly between its members. This year the stage is particularly overstocked, with Ludacris, Akon, Chris Brown with Lil Wayne and Birdman, Diddy with Keyshia Cole and Elephant Man, Ne-Yo, Ciara, Young Jeezy, Mims, Swizz Beatz, Rich Boy and T-Pain. At 6:30 p.m., Giants Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900, meadowlands.com; $40 to $165. (Sisario)

CALVIN JOHNSON, JULIE DOIRON (Tonight) Mr. Johnson, the granddaddy of the Northwest punk scene, is a dedicated pop primitivist whose odes to the uncorrupted child-savage within are delivered in a froggy and purposely tuneless bass that sounds anything but childlike. Ms. Doiron, formerly of the band Eric's Trip, is too talented a songwriter for gimmickry, singing with quiet intensity about the agony of kissing ''the wrong guy.'' At 8, Don Pedro's, 90 Manhattan Avenue, at McKibbin Street, East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, toddpnyc.com. (Sisario)

KINGS OF LEON (Tuesday) All is boogie, boogie, boogie and whine, whine, whine in the Rolling Stones-meets-Lynyrd Skynyrd songs of these three brothers and a cousin from Tennessee, who do the sexy boogie-whine thing as well as it can be done. With Snowden and the Fentures. At 7:30 p.m., Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, roselandballroom.com; sold out. (Sisario)

* LAVENDER DIAMOND (Tomorrow and Sunday) Led by the adorably chirpy-voiced and taffeta-clad Becky Sharp, Lavender Diamond, from Los Angeles, goes the distance with an impressively ornate folk-rock that never loses the sweet tune. With Entrance. Tomorrow at 9 p.m., Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703, maxwellsnj.com; $12. Sunday at 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $15. (Sisario)

LONG BLONDES, NICOLE ATKINS (Wednesday) Kate Jackson of the Long Blondes, from Sheffield, England, has figured out at least one important thing about being a pop star: people listen to you when you look good. Her band has made a splash at home as much for its smart and catchy New Wave update as for Ms. Jackson's vintage skirts and ''Marlene Dietrich-meets-rockabilly chic,'' as one magazine put it. Nicole Atkins, from Neptune City, N.J., is a marvelously talented fantasist with a bit of Stevie Nicks and a bit more of Rufus Wainwright in her, spinning prom-night-beautiful piano ballads with a masterly cinematic sweep. At 8:30 p.m., Luna Lounge, 361 Metropolitan Avenue, at Havemeyer Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (212) 307-7171, lunalounge.com; $12. (Sisario)

ELENI MANDELL (Wednesday) Somewhere between Tom Waits and Suzanne Vega, Eleni Mandell is a Los Angeles songwriter who sets out to conjure her own noirish, folky cabaret domain. At 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $14. (Pareles)

PAGE McCONNELL (Monday) Playing keyboards in Phish, Mr. McConnell grounded the band's jams in earthy soul-rock while at the same time helping push the songs into orbit. On his new, self-titled solo album he's not as adventurous, though he is more reflective, remembering his former band's glory days and asking if he can ''weather not the storm, but the calm.'' At 9 p.m., Fillmore New York at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $30. (Sisario)

* THE NATIONAL (Tonight) This Brooklyn group has built a significant following with flawless, wilting ballads featuring subtly inventive guitar playing by Bryce Dessner and the weary, cynical baritone of Matt Berninger, who seems pained by his ability to conjure cruelties like ''You could have been a legend/But you became a father.'' This last of a five-night sold-out run also features Philistines Jr. At 8, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com. (Sisario)

* NOISETTES (Wednesday) Led by the throaty and uninhibited Shingai Shoniwa, this London band plays grimy, muscular punk-funk punctuated with lighter touches of something like vaudeville. With the Maccabees and Heypenny. At 7:30 p.m., Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; $12. (Sisario)

* PIPETTES (Tuesday) The most lovable kind of retro act, the Pipettes are three young British women who dress in identical polka dots and mimic '60s girl groups in harmonies that are sassy and flirtatious but strictly approximate. With Smoosh and Marit Bergman. At 9 p.m., Highline Ballroom, 431 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 414-5994, highlineballroom.com; $16 in advance, $18 at the door. (Sisario)

ANNIE ROSS (Tuesday) When this jazz legend barks out ''I Got Rhythm,'' she turns this great Gershwin standard into a hipster's credo. If you've got as much rhythm in your body and music in your head as Ms. Ross does at 76, who indeed could ask for anything more? At 7 p.m., Metropolitan Room, 34 West 22nd Street, Flatiron district, (212) 206-0440, metropolitanroom.com; $25 cover, with a two-drink minimum. (Holden)

THE SEA AND CAKE (Thursday) Programmed rhythms and elusive sound samples percolate through airy, wistful pop in the songs of the Sea and Cake, the Chicago group that gives form to the most evanescent yearnings. With the Zincs and Loney, Dear. At 6 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $20. (Pareles)

* RUFUS WAINWRIGHT (Tuesday and Wednesday) There is bad drama and good drama, and nobody does good drama like Rufus Wainwright, who begins a sold-out four-night at the Blender Theater at Gramercy. With Lucy Wainwright Roche (his half-sister) on Tuesday and Joan as Police Woman on Wednesday. At 8 p.m., 127 East 23rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171. (Sisario)
Jazz Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

* AFRO-LATIN JAZZ ORCHESTRA (Tuesday) Though no longer affiliated with Jazz at Lincoln Center, this precision-honed big band is still led by the pianist and arranger Arturo O'Farrill. Here the group plays a benefit for one of its members, the Dominican-born saxophonist Mario Rivera, and welcomes a parade of special guests, including Jazz at Lincoln Center's major-domo, Wynton Marsalis. At 8:30 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Nate Chinen)

AMBROSE AKINMUSIRE SEXTET (Thursday) Ambrose Akinmusire, a trumpeter currently enrolled in the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz Performance, leads a group that includes two of his classmates there, the vibraphonist Chris Dingman and the saxophonist Walter Smith III. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $12; $10 for members. (Chinen)

PHEEROAN AKLAFF/LATASHA NEVADA DIGGS (Tonight and tomorrow night) Mr. akLaff, a drummer equally attracted to spacious free improvisation and earthbound grooves, showcases new music for a quintet with the pianist Michael Cain, the bassist Francis Mbappe and two singers. Opening the evening, Ms. Diggs offers parts of ''Fraud & Coda,'' a work involving vocals, visuals and electronic sound. At 8, the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org; $10. (Chinen)

JAMES CARNEY GROUP (Sunday) James Carney plays Fender Rhodes piano in this venturesome band, alongside the bassist Chris Lightcap and the drummer Mark Ferber. At 9 p.m., Bar 4, 444 Seventh Avenue, at 15th Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 832-9800, myspace.com/konceptionsatbar4; donation, $5. (Chinen)

JAMES CARTER ORGAN TRIO (Wednesday and Thursday) James Carter, the irrepressibly charismatic saxophonist, leads this sturdy and occasionally surprising soul-jazz unit with the Hammond B-3 organist Gerard Gibbs and the drummer Leonard King. (Through June 9.) At 8:30 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $35, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

FREDDY COLE (Thursday) A charismatic and offhandedly urbane vocalist, Mr. Cole takes a broad approach to repertory that nearly disarms comparisons to his older brother Nat. He performs here with another debonair stylist, the tenor saxophonist Houston Person. (Through June 10.) At 8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

ANDREW D'ANGELO TRIO (Thursday) Andrew D'Angelo is a saxophonist and bass clarinetist with a full-throttle approach to free improvisation, as he seems likely to demonstrate in the company of the drummer Fred Kennedy and the bassist Trevor Dunn. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; $5 donation. (Chinen)

CHARLES DAVIS QUARTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) The veteran saxophonist Charles Davis focuses on bebop in this group with the pianist Tardo Hammer, the bassist Lee Hudson and the drummer Jimmy Wormworth. At 8, 10 and 11:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662, smokejazz.com; cover, $28. (Chinen)

JEFF DAVIS BAND (Wednesday) The drummer Jeff Davis has a steady profile in left-of-center New York jazz circles, but he doesn't often lead his own groups. This one consists of Kirk Knuffke on trumpet, Tony Barba on reeds, Jon Goldberger on guitar, Eivind Opsvik on bass and Kris Davis, Mr. Davis's wife, on Fender Rhodes piano. At 10 p.m., Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; $5 donation. (Chinen)

DOMINIQUE EADE AND BRAD SHEPIK (Tomorrow) Ms. Eade weighs a chanteuse's coolness against an exploratory jazz instinct, especially in dialogue with Mr. Shepik, a guitarist. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)

ELDAR (Tuesday) Eldar Djangirov, a piano prodigy from Kyrgyzstan, has a new album, ''re-imagination'' (Masterworks Jazz), that reflects his burgeoning interest in sleek electro-acoustic fusion. At 7:30 p.m., Joe's Pub at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $20, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen)

JOEL FORRESTER (Sunday and Wednesday) Mr. Forrester, a pianist with a wry and omnivorous style, plays unaccompanied on Sunday night in a regular engagement; on Wednesday he leads a trio with David Hofstra on bass and Matt Garrity on drums. Sunday from 8 to midnight, Brandy Library, 25 North Moore Street, TriBeCa, (212) 226-5545, brandylibrary.com; no cover. Wednesday at 8 and 9:45 p.m., Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; no cover, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

JACOB GARCHIK TRIO (Thursday) On his recent album ''Abstracts'' (Yestereve), the trombonist Jacob Garchik offers a bouquet of appealingly compact excursions for this trio with the pianist Jacob Sacks and the drummer Dan Weiss. At 8 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)

PEDRO GIRAUDO JAZZ ORCHESTRA (Monday) The bassist Pedro Giraudo features his own compositions in this large ensemble, which matches jazz protocols to the rhythmic lessons of his native Argentina. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $15. (Chinen)

SUNNY JAIN GROUP (Monday) The drummer Sunny Jain fashions a Southeast Asian jazz aesthetic with help from Rez Abbasi on guitar, Gary Wang on bass and Steve Welsh on saxophones. At 8 p.m., Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; $5 donation. (Chinen)

* GUILLERMO KLEIN Y LOS GAUCHOS (Tuesday through Thursday) Guillermo Klein, a restlessly creative Argentine pianist and composer now based in Barcelona, made his first Village Vanguard appearance last summer. Returning now, he headlines for two weeks with his signature 11-piece band, stocked with talent like the trumpeter Diego Urcola and the saxophonists Chris Cheek and Bill McHenry. (Through June 17.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

KNEEBODY FEATURING THEO BLECKMANN (Tuesday) Blending rock, jazz and funk in a convincing amalgam, Kneebody draws on the skills of improvisers like the trumpeter Shane Endsley and the keyboardist Adam Benjamin. Here they have a special guest in Theo Bleckmann, a texture-oriented vocalist. At 8:30 p.m., Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $12; $8 for students. (Chinen)

KIRK KNUFFKE QUINTET/OHAD TALMOR'S NEWSREEL (Wednesday) Though the trumpeter Kirk Knuffke is the leader of his own avant-garde quintet, it will appear here under the baton of the venerable Butch Morris, another trumpeter and composer. In a later set the saxophonist Ohad Talmor will feature his own compositions for a group with the trumpeter Shane Endsley, the pianist Jacob Sacks, the bassist Matt Pavolka and the drummer Dan Weiss. At 8 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)

MIKE LeDONNE TRIO (Tonight and tomorrow night) Mike LeDonne, an articulate pianist, leads a sharp post-bop trio with the bassist John Webber and the drummer Lewis Nash. At 8 and 9:45, Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; cover, $25, with a $15 minimum. (Chinen)

LOST JAZZ SHRINES: TIN PALACE (Tonight) The Tin Palace, a Bowery nightspot that operated through much of the 1970s, was home not only to jazz but also to a rich Brazilian music scene. Tonight that legacy is remembered in the screening of a documentary film, followed by a performance by the fine Brazilian-born jazz singer Luciana Souza. Film at 7, performance at 8:30, TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, (212) 220-1460, tribecapac.org; $25; $15 for students. (Chinen)

JESSICA LURIE ENSEMBLE (Tonight) Playing saxophone and accordion as well as vocalizing, Jessica Lurie wears many hats in this adventurous but melodic group. It includes another saxophonist, Tina Richerson, on baritone, as well as the bassist Todd Sickafoose and the drummer Allison Miller. At 9 and 10:30, Tea Lounge, 837 Union Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 789-2762, tealoungeny.com; $5 donation. (Chinen)

DONNY McCASLIN GROUP (Sunday) On his strong new album, ''In Pursuit,'' which Sunnyside is releasing next week, the saxophonist Donny McCaslin applies his extroverted style to a Latin American-inspired modern fusion. He does the same here on a smaller scale, with the bassist Boris Kozlov and the guitarist Ben Monder. At 9:30 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, near Seventh Avenue, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)

* NEW LANGUAGES FESTIVAL (Tonight and tomorrow night) This adventurous festival in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is organized in part by the alto saxophonist Aaron Ali Shaikh, who leads a trio tomorrow night at 10. The lineup also includes a duo of the violist Mat Maneri and the drummer Randy Peterson (tonight at 10); Dub Trio, a group devoted to hypnotic groove (tonight at 11:30); and Harriet Tubman, a group led by the guitarist Brandon Ross (tomorrow at 11:30). At 8:30, 10 and 11:30, Rose Live Music, 345 Grand Street, near Marcy Avenue, (718) 599-0069, newlanguages.org; $10. (Chinen)

NICHOLAS PAYTON QUINTET (Thursday) Nicholas Payton, an abundantly gifted trumpeter, has recently oscillated between hard-bop and fusion, producing good results in both areas. The group he leads here -- with Kevin Hays on piano, Vicente Archer on bass, Daniel Sadownick on percussion and Marcus Gilmore on drums -- could move in any direction he chooses. (Through June 10.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $25. (Chinen)

ERIC REED QUARTET (Tuesday through Thursday) Sharp sophistication is a hallmark of the pianist Eric Reed, whose ensemble here features the saxophonist Jeff Clayton, the bassist Gerald Cannon and the drummer Willie Jones III. (Through June 10.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Dizzy's Club Coca-Cola, Frederick P. Rose Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 258-9595, jalc.org; cover, $30, with a minimum of $10 at tables, $5 at the bar. (Chinen)

JASON RIGBY QUARTET (Tonight) ''Translucent Space'' (Fresh Sound New Talent), the most recent album by the saxophonist Jason Rigby, doesn't come by its name casually; it's an album of airy, often diaphanous music, with faint echoes of early fusion and third stream. At 9 and 10:30, Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)

ADAM ROGERS GROUP (Tonight and tomorrow night) As is the case on ''Time and the Infinite'' (Criss Cross), the new album by the guitarist Adam Rogers, this band favors serpentine melodies and a rock-informed rhythmic thrust. At 9 and 10:30, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, at Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063, jazzgallery.org; cover, $15; $10 for members. (Chinen)

* JENNY SCHEINMAN TRIO (Tuesday) Jenny Scheinman is a violinist attracted to rusticity but committed to a modern language. The same could be said, more or less, of the pianist Jason Moran and the drummer Nasheet Waits, innovators (and two-thirds of Mr. Moran's working trio) who join her here. At 7 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)

GRANT STEWART (Tomorrow) Mr. Stewart is a highly proficient tenor saxophonist, as he confirms on his bebop-steeped recent album ''In the Still of the Night'' (Sharp Nine). At 9 and 11:15 p.m., Bar Next Door, 129 Macdougal Street, near West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 529-5945, lalanternacaffe.com; cover, $8. (Chinen)

BEN STREET TRIO (Tuesday) Ben Street, a versatile and ever-supportive bassist, assumes a leadership role in this trio, with Eli Degibri on reeds and Marcus Gilmore on drums. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Louis 649, 649 East Ninth Street, at Avenue C, East Village, (212) 673-1190, louis649.com; no cover. (Chinen)

SUPERGENEROUS (Tuesday and Wednesday) Explosive energies and far-flung timbres define the methodology of Supergenerous, a rhythm-minded collaboration between the percussionist Cyro Baptista and the guitarist Kevin Breit. For this two-night engagement the bassist Ian de Souza joins the fray. At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $20. (Chinen)

DAVID WEISS AND THE POINT OF DEPARTURE QUINTET (Tomorrow) An assertive trumpeter and accomplished arranger, David Weiss leads a strong working band with J. D. Allen on tenor saxophone, Nir Felder on guitar, Matt Clohesy on bass and Rudy Royston on drums. At midnight, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $10, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

Opera

'FALSTAFF' (Tomorrow and Sunday) In its heyday on Bleecker Street, Amato Opera was where young New Yorkers saw their first operas; in its current home on the Bowery, it has taken on a certain quality of camp. But its loyal fans still love it, and it still loves opera, and offers Verdi with all of that love, so that some of the spirit of the opera comes across almost in spite of the variable skills of its performers. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 228-8200, amato.org; $35; $28 for students and 65+. (Anne Midgette)

MANHATTAN PHILHARMONIC (Monday) The mezzo Graciela Araya and the Finnish soprano Eilana Lappalainen join forces with the Manhattan Philharmonic for an all-Italian opera program of Rossini and Cilea, Donizetti and Verdi, backed up by the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York. Peter Tiboris conducts. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $35 to $94. (Midgette)
Classical Music

* AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Sunday) Leon Botstein, a reliable champion of neglected composers, now turns his attention to Mieczyslaw Weinberg, a contemporary and friend of Shostakovich's. Mr. Botstein will conduct Weinberg's Trumpet Concerto, with Carl Albach as soloist, and the United States premiere of the Symphony No. 6. The program concludes with Shostakovich's poignant Symphony No. 13, ''Babi Yar'' (which commemorates the 1941 massacre of more than 30,000 Russian Jews), featuring the Concert Chorale of New York and the bass baritone Sergei Leiferkus. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $27 to $55. (Vivien Schweitzer)

* BANG ON A CAN MARATHON (Tomorrow) For its 20th anniversary, this eclectic, trailblazing, committed and tireless collective of composers, performers and presenters will offer a nonstop, 26-hour marathon of new and recent music at the World Financial Center's Winter Garden, part of the River to River Festival. Organizers promise a ''round-the-clock mix of mind-boggling, genre-bending music,'' and with a lineup including the composers Evan Ziporyn, Louis Andriessen and Meredith Monk; the contemporary-music ensembles Eighth Blackbird and Ethel; and even the adventurous Young People's Chorus of New York, there is no reason to doubt them. Stop by, take pillows, come and go, or settle in for the long haul. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. through Sunday at 10 p.m., West Street, south of Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505, bangonacan.org or rivertorivernyc.com; free. (Anthony Tommasini)

* BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'GLOBAL FEMINISMS,' through July 1. Too much of the work in this assembly of pieces by nearly 90 women from nearly 50 countries is body-oriented and doesn't venture beyond the essentialism of Judy Chicago's indomitable 1975-79 installation opus, ''The Dinner Party,'' whose enshrinement in the new Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art this exhibition celebrates. Thoroughly dominated by photography and video, with a documentary slant to many of its better moments, the show is more about information, politics and the struggle for equality than it is about art in any very concentrated or satisfying sense. That doesn't keep parts of it from being energetic and illuminating. 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Roberta Smith)

BROOKLYN MUSEUM: 'KINDRED SPIRITS: ASHER B. DURAND AND THE AMERICAN LANDSCAPE,' through July 29. This show of about 60 works by Durand has as its centerpiece ''Kindred Spirits'' (1849), a tribute to the landscapist Thomas Cole and his friend the poet and journalist William Cullen Bryant. A founder of the Hudson River School, Durand (1796-1886) favored the realistic approach to landscape. He explored forest interiors with close attention to the ways of trees, foliage and rocks and ground cover in smaller works, while his larger and more elaborate exhibition pictures, influenced by European masters, are Arcadian visions suffused with light, color and atmospheric perspective. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org. (Grace Glueck)

GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM: 'DIVISIONISM/NEO-IMPRESSIONISM: ARCADIA AND ANARCHY,' through Aug. 6. Ultimately this rare, compressed, mercurial exhibition of work by the Italian Divisionists of the 1890s is long on history and short on truly convincing paintings. The inclusion of works by Seurat and his French, Dutch and Belgian followers clarifies how the Italians pushed Pointillism, Seurat's invention, in all directions: toward realism, academic classicism, Symbolism, class consciousness and even Impressionism. The show opens a new, albeit small, window on the genesis of Modernism beyond the French canon. If many of the works are period pieces, they are also immensely appealing, big-hearted and physically robust period pieces. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500. (Smith)

* INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'BIOGRAPHICAL LANDSCAPE: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF STEPHEN SHORE, 1969-1979,' through Sept. 9. In 1971 the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave Stephen Shore its second-ever exhibition by a living photographer. (Alfred Stieglitz had the first.) He was 23 when it opened. What he did makes up most of this wonderful show. Mr. Shore has reprinted the photographs digitally, with rejuvenated colors as fresh and subtle as the day the pictures were shot. The work's laconic eloquence speaks of an era and a nation. Its wit and affection add buoyancy to scenes of threadbare America from a moment when the country was depressed by war and years of civil unrest. Its formal rigor makes an uncanny order out of images that, at first glance, look like no place or nothing. Look again. His show reminds us of a period when cutting-edge American art and the tradition of straight, documentary photography got together. 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at West 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000. (Michael Kimmelman)

* INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY: 'LET YOUR MOTTO BE RESISTANCE: AFRICAN AMERICAN PORTRAITS,' through Sept. 9. This show of photographic portraits is a praise-song in pictures, a shout-out to history. It's also a fancy-dress inaugural party for the yet-to-be-built National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington. It tends to be a little too fancy, too heavy on glitz, too short on grit. Still, what a party it is, with a Who's Who of charismatic black statesmen, from Frederick Douglass to Malcolm X, and with Leontyne Price, Mahalia Jackson and the Supremes sharing a stage. (See above.) (Holland Cotter)

THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'IMPRESSIONIST AND EARLY MODERN PAINTINGS:THE CLARK BROTHERS COLLECT,' through Aug. 19. The Met examines the lives and collecting habits of two feuding brothers, heirs to the Singer sewing machine fortune, who were among the leading 20th-century art patrons. Sterling Clark was founder of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass. His younger brother Stephen was a trustee of both the Met and the Museum of Modern Art (and established the National Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.) The brothers shared a love of Renoir, Degas and Americans like Winslow Homer, but Sterling ''drew the line'' at Cézanne and considered Matisse and Picasso ''bad painters and fakers.'' Tracking their taste and how they dispersed their collections is interesting -- and perhaps instructive for contemporary collectors. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Martha Schwendener)

* THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART: 'POIRET: KING OF FASHION,' through Aug. 5. A revolutionary in revolutionary times, the fashion designer Paul Poiret introduced unstructured garments that freed women from corsets in 1906, the year before Picasso committed his decidedly uninhibited (and unstaid) ''Demoiselles d'Avignon'' to canvas. But the modern painter whom Poiret most resembles, in his love of the exotic, his brilliant use of color and pattern and his penchant for simplified, almost rudimentary form, is Matisse. This rare exhibition -- from the Met's Costume Institute -- does his sartorial genius justice with a spare installation rendered radiant by hand-painted silk backdrops of the leafy parks and luxurious drawing rooms of Paris. (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Smith)

THE MET: 'FRANK STELLA: PAINTING INTO ARCHITECTURE,' through July 29. Crammed into a gallery that feels like an obstacle course, this exhibition spans 43 years with 25 paintings, reliefs, drawings and architectural models, all with the goal of tracing an evolution that has not yet occurred. Taking up most of the space are enlarged versions of models that are considered sculptures -- and that look as if they date from the early 1960s. The main draws are the examples of the paintings and reliefs that are the basis of Mr. Stella's importance as an artist. (See above.) (Smith)

THE MET: 'FRANK STELLA ON THE ROOF,' through Oct. 28. Two large Pop Art sculptures, two architectural models and a model enlarged into a sculpture-installation piece confirm that one of the greatest American artists of the postwar era doesn't do himself or anyone else any favors when he strays from the wall to work fully in the round. The results have a certain Stella-like verve but are otherwise generic. (See above.) (Smith)

MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM: 'APOCALYPSE THEN: MEDIEVAL ILLUMINATIONS FROM THE MORGAN,' through June 17. The symbolism of the Book of Revelation, with its demons and lakes of fire, has a subversive appeal. This exhibition at the Morgan Library celebrates a facsimile of ''Las Huelgas Apocalypse'' (1220), the largest surviving Spanish illuminated commentary on the Apocalypse. The show, which includes 50 leaves from the original text, unbound and installed around the gallery's perimeter, offers a walking tour of the medieval imagination. 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, morganlibrary.org. (Andrea K. Scott)

* EL MUSEO DEL BARRIO: 'THE DISAPPEARED (LOS DESAPARECIDOS),' through June 17. The most potent show of contemporary political art of the season, and one of the most moving shows of any kind in the city right now. The title refers to a peculiarly chilling form of violence associated with political upheavals in Latin America over the past 40 years, and now becoming more common in Iraq. 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272, elmuseo .org. (Cotter)

MUSEUM OF MODERN ART: 'COMIC ABSTRACTION: IMAGE-BREAKING, IMAGE-MAKING,' through June 11. This unimaginative and uniformed treatment of a big idea -- the healthy and essential contamination of Modernist abstraction by popular culture -- should be seen if only because it is such a dispiriting symptom of the Modern's paralysis where contemporary art is concerned. Including 30 works by 13 artists from the last 16 years, it alternates between the literal and the arbitrary and favors sincere political intent over genuine artistic quality. Although it promises work that addresses ''perplexing questions,'' nearly everything here is perfectly pleasant and innocuous. The exceptions are provided by Gary Simmons, Ellen Gallagher and Sue Williams. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (212) 708-9400, moma.org. (Smith)

STOREFRONT FOR ART AND ARCHITECTURE: 'CCCP: COSMIC COMMUNIST CONSTRUCTIONS PHOTOGRAPHED,' through June 16. This show, packed with obscure architectural gems, reopens on Tuesday. Covering a period ignored by academics and mainstream architects, it relies almost exclusively on the photographs of Frédéric Chaubin, who spent five years traveling across the former Soviet Union, uncovering forgotten architectural works in cities like Tbilisi, Yalta and Yerevan. The results are a revelation. Among the outright gems is Georgy Chakhava's 1975 Roads Ministry building, a monumental grid of interlocking concrete forms rising on a steep, wooded site in Tbilisi, Georgia. Set on an incline between two highways, the building's heavy, cantilevered forms reflect the Soviet-era penchant for heroic scale. Yet they also relate sensitively to their context, celebrating the natural landscape that flows directly underneath the building. What's refreshing about this exhibition is its lack of an ideological agenda: it is open to all sorts of possibilities. The Gaudíesque romanticism of a sanitarium in Druskininkai, Lithuania, for example, spins the aesthetic off in yet another direction. Compelling and easy to digest, this show piques our interest in ways that some larger institutions, ever more averse to risk, often fail to do. 97 Kenmare Street, Little Italy, (212) 431-5795, storefrontnews.org. (Nicolai Ouroussoff)

WHITNEY MUSEUM AT ALTRIA: MATTHEW BRANNON, 'WHERE WERE WE,' through Aug. 26. Matthew Brannon brings together art, poetry and advertising in a series of letterpress prints that hark back to 1950s and 1960s textile designs by Astrid Sampe and Marimekko. Texts written by the artist and accompanying the images read like song lyrics crossed with Conceptual Art and Language Poetry (which emphasized experimentalism and reader interaction). Consumption and excess are frequent references, as well as how art, design and fashion feed these modern yet primordial urges and desires. 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453, whitney.org. (Schwendener)

WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'LINCOLN KIRSTEIN,' through Aug. 27. In the middle of the last century Lincoln Kirstein particularly relished attacking the Museum of Modern Art. Pure abstraction was ridiculous, he thought. It had no standards. Against Mondrian and Pollock, he endorsed, among others, the artists in this show. They are the sculptors Elie Nadelman and Gaston Lachaise and the painters Paul Cadmus, who was Kirstein's brother-in-law, Walker Evans and Pavel Tchelitchew. With the exception of Evans, Kirstein's taste clearly hasn't won the day, but it's never bad to re-examine received opinions or to be reminded of a generous advocate. 945 Madison Avenue at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600. (Kimmelman)

* WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'SUMMER OF LOVE: ART OF THE PSYCHEDELIC ERA,' through Sept. 16. Tear gas, pot and patchouli were the scents of the 1960s. You can almost detect the last two wafting through this two-floor display of rock posters, light shows, photographs and paintings. But the burn of tear gas, with the association of political emergency it brings, is missing in a show that remembers a lot, but forgets much more, about what was happening 40 years ago, when America was losing its mind to save, some would say, its soul. (See above.) (Cotter)

* MARTIN KIPPENBERGER: PREIS PAINTINGS Seven canvases from two series of paintings rarely exhibited in this country play on the double German meaning of preis (price and prize), some variation of which appears on each surface. They show this famous bad-boy sculptor conveying his usual sarcasm in surprisingly beautiful terms that couldn't get much flatter. Hard-edged and brushy techniques contrast the main tactics of formalist painting while converting the Modernist grid into designs redolent of drapery and checked tablecloths. A preponderance of hot pink argues for the pleasure principle. 1018 Art, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 537-0453, www.1018art.net, through July 27. (Smith)

OLIVER TWIST Each month this new gallery will rent its space to hip out-of-town galleries, a plan that could unsettle the home-away balance of powers in New York. The inaugural show, while something of a mish-mash, presents works by 29 artists represented by the renters of the coming season. Enjoy the sixth-floor space's Chelsea-like light and view, and stay tuned. Rental, 120 East Broadway, at Allen Street, Lower East Side, (212) 608-6002, through June 16. (Smith)
Public Art

MAD. SQ. ART 2007: ROXY PAINE This installation is made up of two stainless-steel tree sculptures -- ''Conjoined'' and ''Defunct'' -- and a glacierlike boulder, ''Erratic,'' by Mr. Paine. The tree sculptures are made from thousands of pieces of metal pipe and rod elements that have been cut, welded and polished. They are real enough to resemble actual trees but not so real that they form a continuum with the surrounding foliage. What captures your immediate attention is ''Conjoined,'' a 40-foot-tall-by-45-foot-wide sculpture of two trees whose gleaming steel branches cantilever and then improbably connect in midair. It is impossible to tell where the branches of one tree begin, and the other's end. But the piece is also beautifully eccentric, a futuristic fantasy of streamlined vegetation manufactured in imitation of the real thing, only much more appealing and exciting. Madison Square Park, 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, (212) 538-4689, www.madisonsquarepark.org, through Dec. 31. (Benjamin Genocchio)
Last Chance

* MEQUITTA AHUJA AND CHARLES RITCHIE Ms. Ahuja makes her New York solo debut with large paintings on paper of mythical beings,half woman, half animal, dressed in robes as brilliantly colored as the tropical fruit and flowers around them. Referring to the artist's African-American and East Indian background, the pictures turn marginality into a regal condition. The gallery also kicks off its new artist's book program with a display of sketch books by Mr. Ritchie, an artist based in Maryland. Each small book is filled with marvelous watercolors and all but indecipherable writing. Mr. Ritchie has been making such books for 30 years. They are extraordinary. BravinLee Programs, 526 West 26th Street, 2nd floor, (212) 462-4406, closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

* FRANCESCO CLEMENTE: WORKS, 1971-1979 A selection of nearly 70 little-known early drawings and intriguing photo-works shows this young, restless proto-Neo-Expressionist overcoming the gravitational pull of Arte Povera and Conceptual Art, and broaching themes of the body, sexuality and the inner life that would blossom in his large paintings of the 1980s. Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, SoHo, (212) 343-7300; closes tomorrow. (Smith)

* JOANNA MALINOWSKA Joanna Malinowska traveled to windswept Baffin Island in the Canadian Arctic last year in the footsteps of the anthropologist Franz Boas, who studied the Inuit there a century ago. The subject of Ms. Malinowska's research turns out to be a Native American musician and Elvis impersonator named Jimmy Ekho, and the film they made together is funny and moving. For another video Ms. Malinowska set a solar-powered boom-box in the middle of the Arctic wasteland, where it will play Glenn Gould's 1981 version of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' for as long as the sun shines. Venetia Kapernekas Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, eighth floor, (212) 462-4150, closes tomorrow. (Cotter)

WHITNEY MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART: 'GORDON MATTA-CLARK RETROSPECTIVE' I have no doubt that Matta-Clark is now being turned into a hot commercial commodity, but at least at the Whitney you can see what he aspired to be. He came up with various wonderfully harebrained ideas. Literally, in one case: after letting his hair grow for a year, he cut it off as a kind of performance and phrenological gag. The preserved hair, dutifully tagged piece by piece, opens the show like a holy relic. At the center of the exhibition is ''Splitting.'' To a plain single-family suburban frame house in Englewood, N.J., he made a cut straight down the middle, bisecting the building, then severing the four corners of the roof. The retrospective consists of films, drawings, photographs and some of the architectural pieces he cut out of buildings. The drawings are casual and not too interesting, but the luxurious black-and-white photographs from Paris speak more to Matta-Clark's formal elegance. The big message was: Life as art, and art as life, a philosophy dependent on our being properly attuned and keen to the moment. (212) 570-3676, whitney.org, closes on Sunday. (Kimmelman)
